title: Which is the correct way to use either 'who' or 'whom' in the following paragraph? “God may guide and direct her to evangelize to specific unsaved people who God intends to save according to His plan.” - Quora

response.answer_text: The answer is “people whom.” That is because “people” in this case are the receivers of the action. It’s a case of subject versus object. People in this sentence are not the subject of the sentence (doing the action), they are the object, or receivers of the action. For some additional help on this topic, see below. WHO and WHOM WHO and WHOM are used as personal pronouns and refer to people, but choosing between the two can be confusing: RULE: WHO/WHOEVER always substitute for subject pronouns: I, YOU, SHE, HE, and THEY. WHOM/WHOMEVER always substitute for object pronouns: ME, HER, HIM, and THEM. So, what is the correct word to use in this case? "Who/whom is the party for? If you answer the question, the right choice becomes clear: "The party is for him." Hence, the right choice is WHOM. Tip: A good way to decide the issue is to substitute HE or HIM (or She or Her) for WHO or WHOM. Then it is fairly easy to see which sounds the best. Make it a statement that answers the question if that helps you. EXAMPLES · For who/whom are these boxes? (The boxes are for her) (whom) · The girl who/whom went to Tampa. (She went to Tampa) (who) · Who/whom were they after? (They were after him) (whom) · I’ll tell whoever/whomever wants to listen. (I’ll tell him) (whomever) · Whoever/whomever parks here will be ticketed. (He parks) (whoever)
